history.content:
I have the perspective of one upper div philosophy: PHILOS 149 (Special Topics in Logic) 

I imagine this course had a lighter load than most philosophy courses as we only had weekly homework assignments (short and easy), section/lectures, and a final research paper.

I enjoyed it very much but all my CS courses had larger workloads for sure.

children.subject:
Yes, I took 149 immediately after 12A which I took about a year after 70. 12A is enough as a prerequisite, and 70 provides additional foundation.

It's a logic class in the end, so as long as you have the ability to grasp logic concepts you will do well. I really loved 149, so I hope it's structured in the same way as when I took it.

Currently taking Philos 140A here without having taken 12A. The professor said 70 is enough as an alternative to 12A at the beginning of the semester and I haven't felt that there is any disadvantage from not taking 12A, but I'm not sure if this is the case for all 14X classes. Really enjoying the class so far and the workload is pretty light, with just weekly problem sets that are way less time-consuming than the ones you get in 70 or other CS classes.
I am the op and want to ask the student answer that did you take 149 after philos 12A? Do you think 70 + a bit reading should be enough preparation for taking it with a letter grade?
I'm not the same anon, but how is the workload for Philos 133? Are there problem sets for this, or readings + papers?

Hi!! I am so happy that you are considering this course. I took this course with the same Professor who will be teaching it next semester. It's a really great class and the Professor is one of the best I have met. Strongly recommended!

Workload wise, it is made up of 6 study questions (25%) in the whole semester (each of the study question has like 5-6 questions and you just have to answer in a paragraph, and those questions are not too demanding, but requires some thinking and understanding of the materials). And then 2 papers (25% each) and 1 comprehensive final exam (25%, they give you all possible questions they will ask). I would say it's really manageable and not too much workload. Maybe about half the workload of a normal CS upper div (or even less)?
Thank you for the detailed response; that sounds like a really great course!

Hi I also major in philosophy so I hope this answer could help!

For classes that are more on philosophy side rather than logic side, there's reading every week (and how much workload that would be really varies by person), and there are usually 3 papers in total/2-3 papers+1 final comprehensive exam. Sometimes some classes have little assignments like short responses but that's usually very short and just aim to let you understand the material. The overall workload is not too big compared to an upper div CS class. But you need to spend a lot of time reading and when it comes to doing the paper you need to spend time on that too:) If you have specific classes in mind feel free to follow up with me and I can give you a more accurate estimate:)

For classes that are more on the logic side, usually weekly problem sets, take-home midterm and a final paper. The style is similar to upper div Math class but workload is smaller. Way smaller workload compared to CS upper div problem sets.

history.content: Can anybody comment on the workload of upper div philosophy class (letter grade) compared to any cs courses? Especially classes that are more on philosophy side rather than logic side
